webTitle: Vorsprung durch technik: US tech giants v Germany in the driverless car race

fields.bodyText: The Here deal represents Audi, BMW and Daimler’s fightback against a tech sector encroaching on carmaker territory. Three German carmakers have put their rivalries aside by teaming up to acquire a €2.8bn (£2bn) mapping business from Nokia, in a bid to outsmart tech groups in the race to cash in on the driverless car revolution. However, the German trio are taking on businesses who possess considerable cash resources and who are not encumbered by the need to develop conventional vehicles at the same time. Google Google has long been a pioneer in the race towards driverless motoring, recently setting up its own car company, Google Auto LLC. The company is headed by Chris Urmson, project lead for Google’s self-driving cars. The company is registered with national and international organisations as a passenger vehicle manufacturer, and was licensed last year as a carmaker in California. Documents obtained by the Guardian under a Public Records Act request in California show that Google Auto was formed as a limited liability company in late 2011. Initially, Google used it to modify and test the fleet of driverless Lexus SUVs that succeeded the company’s first self-driving Prius saloons. Google Auto is named as the manufacturer of all 23 autonomous Lexus cars registered with California’s department of motor vehicles, including all the vehicles involved in a recent spate of minor accidents in and around Google’s home town of Mountain View. Apple The consumer electronics giant is apparently working on an electric car or vehicle-related project that could be released by 2020. The Cupertino, California-based company behind the iPhone and Mac computer, was reported earlier this year to have been on a recruitment spree, attracting key members of car manufacturers’ electric and new vehicle system teams. There have also been reports of a visit by senior Apple executives to a BMW plant in Leipzig, Germany, fuelling rumours that the two groups might be about to announce a formal link-up to possibly develop futuristic cars. A report from Bloomberg indicates that Apple is targeting an electric car for release as early as 2020. Vehicles typically take seven years to develop. Tesla Perhaps the closest to being ready for going driverless is Tesla Motors, whose chief executive, tech pioneer Elon Musk, unveiled a software update last week that would allow its cars to autosteer and park. Musk said, in a series of tweets, that his company was “almost ready to release highway autosteer and parallel autopark software update”, a sign that the technology was nearing a state of readiness. He conceded, however, that the software still had work to do before it could decipher road markings at dusk. Tesla has for months been testing its driverless software prototypes on highways north of San Francisco.

webTitle: Reserve Bank of Australia keeps the cash rate at 2% – as it happened

fields.bodyText: The focus will undoubtedly be about the dollar. Stevens move away from jawboning the currency downwards has sent the market into a mini-frenzy. After months of steady falls, the dollar has jumped more than 1%. Was US72c the bottom? We’ll find out in the coming months. But thanks for joining us today. RBA keeps the cash rate at 2%. Governor Glenn Stevens seems a little more upbeat The dollar spikes nearly US1c in response “Accommodative” policy (ie low rates) to continue Conclusion among market watchers seems to be that RBA is more upbeat and the dollar has responded by rising strongly since 2.30pm. The local unit is now at US73.51c – a gain of nearly one cent on the last 24 hours trading. And this from The Kouk, who thinks the next move might be up... The governor’s statement kept up the cut and past right through to the conclusion. A month ago this was the conclusion to the statement: The Board today judged that leaving the cash rate unchanged was appropriate at this meeting. Information on economic and financial conditions to be received over the period ahead will inform the Board’s assessment of the outlook and hence whether the current stance of policy will most effectively foster sustainable growth and inflation consistent with the target. Here is this month’s conclusion, with the difference in bold: The Board today judged that leaving the cash rate unchanged was appropriate at this meeting. Further information on economic and financial conditions to be received over the period ahead will inform the Board’s ongoing assessment of the outlook and hence whether the current stance of policy will most effectively foster sustainable growth and inflation consistent with the target. “Further” and “ongoing”. Reading the governor’s statement for signs does get a bit like using tea leaves to forecast future events, but even the most ambitious fortune teller would struggle to find meaning from the addition of just those two words! One change was on the issue of the exchange rate. Last month it noted that it was “likely and necessary” for the dollar to fall but this month simply said it was “adjusting to the significant declines in key commodity prices”. In the few minutes since the announcement, the value of the dollar has risen from around US$0.72990 to US$0.7330 - a rise of 0.5%, which isn’t a great deal, and pretty much the usual after such announcements. And more on that housing market issue ... It notes that: Low interest rates are acting to support borrowing and spending. Credit is recording moderate growth overall, with stronger borrowing by businesses and growth in lending to the housing market broadly steady over recent months. Its concerns about a housing bubble – such as they are – remain the same as they were last month, with the bank noting that “dwelling prices continue to rise strongly in Sydney, though trends have been more varied in a number of other cities”. It also again notes that: The Bank is working with other regulators to assess and contain risks that may arise from the housing market. In other asset markets, prices for equities and commercial property have been supported by lower long-term interest rates. So nothing new on the RBA front. On the international front the RBA notes that: The Federal Reserve is expected to start increasing its policy rate later this year, but some other major central banks are continuing to ease policy. Hence, global financial conditions remain very accommodative. Despite fluctuations in markets associated with the respective developments in China and Greece, long-term borrowing rates for most sovereigns and creditworthy private borrowers remain remarkably low. Rather wonderfully that is exactly word for word what it said last month on the same issue. Never let it be said that the RBA lets good sentences go to waste. Each statement by the RBA generally involves a fair degree of cut and paste, and this one is almost verbatim the same as last month’s. But there is a slight difference in the paragraph on the domestic economy. This month it added in an new part when it noted that: While the rate of growth has been somewhat below longer-term averages, it has been associated with somewhat stronger growth of employment and a steady rate of unemployment over the past year. This is a nod to the speech by Glenn Stevens which suggests we are in a period where lower GDP growth is not leading to slower employment growth. And the usual on the housing market... “The Bank is working with other regulators to assess and contain risks that may arise from the housing market.” “Low interest rates are acting to support borrowing and spending.” “Policy must be accommodative.” Here’s the statement in full. Rates on hold at 2%. But this brings with it a couple questions: 1. Is growth below average and thus the RBA should keep thinking about cutting rates? 2. If this is the new average, then does that mean the RBA is happy that monetary policy has done all it can, and there is no need to cut rates any further? It will be interesting to see if the RBA announcement addresses any of these aspects. We wait and see in a couple of minutes ... The new normal? A big question posed by the governor of the RBA, Glenn Stevens, last month was what is “the new normal”? We are currently experiencing abnormally low inflation and wages growth, our economy is growing below average, and yet employment is not falling as would be expected. Stevens suggested this all may be due to statistical flubs which will be corrected in due course (always a possibility), that maybe our population growth has not been as strong as previously thought and thus we’re not getting the usual benefit from such growth. Or maybe, it is that what was once normal GDP growth of 3.2% is now above average. Certainly the slow GDP per capita growth over the past 7 years would suggest things are not going along as usual: Falls in our exchange rate generally lead to rises in the cost of our imports. For now that really hasn’t been that big of a deal, because there was also a big fall in the price of oil (which alas, has now stopped falling and is back rising). The rise in the price of goods and services which has a price determined on the world market (such as petrol and other imported goods) fell 0.3% in the past year: The increase in the price of “non-tradable” goods and services – ie those which sees the price largely determined here in Australia, such as education, health costs, (some) food rose just 2.6%. This is well down on historical averages. And certainly nothing there would have the RBA worried about inflation getting out of control. Indeed, given the weak inflation and weak wages growth figures, the RBA probably wouldn’t mind a bit more inflation. The Treasurer certainly would as stronger inflation and wage growth would see better tax revenue. Two reasons for the low dollar. Firstly iron ore and coal prices plummeted. When a third of a country’s exports fall, the value of that country’s currency will usually fall with it Secondly, the other big factor has been the improvement in the US economy and significantly the end of the US Federal Reserve’s policy of quantitative easing – where it bought a slew of US treasury bonds (around $3.5 trillion all up). That policy devalued the worth of the US dollar. Now that it has finished, the value has improved. Since October last year the US dollar has increased in value by about 10% compared to its major trading partners. Coupled with this is that after nearly seven years, both the Fed and Bank of England are looking like raising their official interest rates. The last time the Fed cut was in December 2008 – a time so long ago Malcolm Turnbull had only just got used to being called “opposition leader”, the most popular movie in Australia was the first Twilight film and Lady Gaga was the newest music sensation with Poker Face. In the time since the Fed last changed interest rates, the RBA has changed them 19 times! But the upshot is, if the Fed raises rates, it will have essentially the same (if not more) impact on the value of our currency as would the RBA cutting rates. So there will be little need for the RBA to worry about that when it makes up its mind in the next half hour. The dollar One reason given in the past for the need for an interest rate cut has been to get the value of our dollar down. Such a worry is well in the past now. Our dollar is worth around US$0.73 – roughly on or just a touch below the 30 year average, and 22% down on where it was in September last year: The slowing of the building approvals is happening pretty much across the country. Of the states, only Tasmania appears to be showing signs of continued vigour. The impact of the new Apra speed limits has also seen banks move to try to dampen the investor market themselves. All four of the big banks have in the past month raised the interest rates for investor housing loans by around 27 to 29 basis points. This is exactly would you would expect to see occur with such “macroprudential tools”. Essentially what they hope will occur is that with a limit on investor lending, it takes some of the heat out of the property market, and allows the RBA to keep rates lower for longer. Certainly the drop in non-housing approvals is a pretty obvious result. A couple of months ago it looked like for the first time non-housing approvals would be greater than housing approvals. Now that landmark looks to be put off for a bit longer: The fall in approvals of apartments – which are basically investor led construction (you don’t have many owner occupiers building an apartment block!) – comes off the back of some interesting findings regarding investor activity. Figures which showed a jump in the numbers of properties being listed for sale in Sydney and Melbourne could be a sign that investors are rushing to get out of the market. Any changes in investor habits is largely being driven by moves by the Apra to limit such lending. Last year it introduced “speed limits” wherein banks should not have credit growth for investor property loans going over 10%. As Martin Farrer reported last week “the Commonwealth (10.2%), NAB (14%) and ANZ (12%) all topped the cap while Westpac, at 9.9%, just scraped below the limit”. The most recent figures from the RBA show overall housing investor credit growing at 10.7% well in excess of that for owner-occupiers at 5.5% Last week also saw the release of the important building approvals data. The RBA knows its most direct impact on the economy through cutting or raising interest rates comes via the building industry – specifically the residential market. The latest figures showed a sharp drop in building approvals – falling 8.2% in seasonally adjusted terms, and 1.2% in trend terms. The drop was driven by a large fall in the number of approvals of non-house dwellings – ie flats and apartments. As I noted a couple weeks ago, there is a large amount of such buildings which have been approved but on which building has yet to begin. This has led some to worry that there is a glut of apartment buildings coming down the construction tube. The number of private sector non-house dwellings approved fell 20.8% in June. And while again those figures do bounce around a lot, the trend fall of 2.4% suggests it is not a flash in the pan occurrence: Overall private sector building approvals rose 14.5% in the past year, but this also is down on previous months and suggests a peak has occurred. Retail sales up Any hopes of a cut in rates were probably smashed with the release of the retail trade figures today. They showed total turnover increased 0.7% in June in seasonally adjusted terms. That’s a pretty sizeable jump, but the seasonally adjusted figures do get a bit excitable. The trend growth of 0.3% is still nice and solid and produced a healthy annual increase of 4.7%: This month also saw the quarterly release of volume of retail sales. It showed as well solid results, with total volume of sales up 3.3% in the past year, with the best results in the household goods retailing , which was up 10.5%: That category includes electrical, computer and other assorted goods, and it certainly saw a bounce due to the release of the iphone 6 last year. The market expectations of interest rates haven’t changed a great deal in the past month. But if anything the market now remains more sure that another rate cut will occur – it’s just that they expect it will come later than it previously expected. A month ago the market was expecting another rate cut anytime from the start of next year on. Now that expectation has been pushed out to April 2016. Of course predictions this far out have a habit of being out by a large amount. It’s worth remembering that in April this year, the market was expecting rates by now to already have been cut to 1.75%. So being wrong four months out suggests we don’t place too much faith in expectations for what will occur next year. Good afternoon. Greg Jericho here. Today most economists agree with the market pricing that suggests there is only a small chance of a rate cut. The market currently is pricing in just a 9% chance of a rate cut. The decision comes after the release of the latest inflation and cost of living data late last month. The data showed that inflation remains very weak at just 1.5%, while the RBA’s “core inflation” measure of just 2.2% is well in the bottom half of its 2% to 3% range. But low inflation does not necessarily mean the RBA is going to pull the trigger and cut rates. fields.body:
7.10am BST

The focus will undoubtedly be about the dollar. Stevens move away from jawboning the currency downwards has sent the market into a mini-frenzy.

After months of steady falls, the dollar has jumped more than 1%. Was US72c the bottom? We’ll find out in the coming months. But thanks for joining us today.

6.31am BST

SUMMARY

  • RBA keeps the cash rate at 2%.
  • Governor Glenn Stevens seems a little more upbeat
  • The dollar spikes nearly US1c in response
  • “Accommodative” policy (ie low rates) to continue

6.25am BST

Conclusion among market watchers seems to be that RBA is more upbeat and the dollar has responded by rising strongly since 2.30pm.

The local unit is now at US73.51c – a gain of nearly one cent on the last 24 hours trading.

Updated at 7.03am BST

6.03am BST

Reaction

And this from The Kouk, who thinks the next move might be up...

5.52am BST

The governor’s statement kept up the cut and past right through to the conclusion. A month ago this was the conclusion to the statement:

The Board today judged that leaving the cash rate unchanged was appropriate at this meeting. Information on economic and financial conditions to be received over the period ahead will inform the Board’s assessment of the outlook and hence whether the current stance of policy will most effectively foster sustainable growth and inflation consistent with the target.

Here is this month’s conclusion, with the difference in bold:

The Board today judged that leaving the cash rate unchanged was appropriate at this meeting. Further information on economic and financial conditions to be received over the period ahead will inform the Board’s ongoing assessment of the outlook and hence whether the current stance of policy will most effectively foster sustainable growth and inflation consistent with the target.

“Further” and “ongoing”. Reading the governor’s statement for signs does get a bit like using tea leaves to forecast future events, but even the most ambitious fortune teller would struggle to find meaning from the addition of just those two words!

5.47am BST

One change was on the issue of the exchange rate. Last month it noted that it was “likely and necessary” for the dollar to fall but this month simply said it was “adjusting to the significant declines in key commodity prices”.

In the few minutes since the announcement, the value of the dollar has risen from around US$0.72990 to US$0.7330 - a rise of 0.5%, which isn’t a great deal, and pretty much the usual after such announcements.

Updated at 6.22am BST

5.44am BST

And more on that housing market issue ...

It notes that:

Low interest rates are acting to support borrowing and spending. Credit is recording moderate growth overall, with stronger borrowing by businesses and growth in lending to the housing market broadly steady over recent months.

Its concerns about a housing bubble – such as they are – remain the same as they were last month, with the bank noting that “dwelling prices continue to rise strongly in Sydney, though trends have been more varied in a number of other cities”.

It also again notes that:

The Bank is working with other regulators to assess and contain risks that may arise from the housing market. In other asset markets, prices for equities and commercial property have been supported by lower long-term interest rates.

So nothing new on the RBA front.

5.42am BST

On the international front the RBA notes that:

The Federal Reserve is expected to start increasing its policy rate later this year, but some other major central banks are continuing to ease policy. Hence, global financial conditions remain very accommodative. Despite fluctuations in markets associated with the respective developments in China and Greece, long-term borrowing rates for most sovereigns and creditworthy private borrowers remain remarkably low.

Rather wonderfully that is exactly word for word what it said last month on the same issue. Never let it be said that the RBA lets good sentences go to waste.

5.40am BST

Each statement by the RBA generally involves a fair degree of cut and paste, and this one is almost verbatim the same as last month’s.

But there is a slight difference in the paragraph on the domestic economy.

This month it added in an new part when it noted that:

While the rate of growth has been somewhat below longer-term averages, it has been associated with somewhat stronger growth of employment and a steady rate of unemployment over the past year.

This is a nod to the speech by Glenn Stevens which suggests we are in a period where lower GDP growth is not leading to slower employment growth.

5.38am BST

And the usual on the housing market...

“The Bank is working with other regulators to assess and contain risks that may arise from the housing market.”

5.37am BST

“Low interest rates are acting to support borrowing and spending.”

5.36am BST

GOVERNOR'S STATEMENT

“Policy must be accommodative.”

Here’s the statement in full.

Updated at 5.50am BST

5.30am BST

RATES ON HOLD!

Rates on hold at 2%.

5.27am BST

But this brings with it a couple questions:

1. Is growth below average and thus the RBA should keep thinking about cutting rates?

2. If this is the new average, then does that mean the RBA is happy that monetary policy has done all it can, and there is no need to cut rates any further?

It will be interesting to see if the RBA announcement addresses any of these aspects.

We wait and see in a couple of minutes ...

5.26am BST

The new normal?

A big question posed by the governor of the RBA, Glenn Stevens, last month was what is “the new normal”? We are currently experiencing abnormally low inflation and wages growth, our economy is growing below average, and yet employment is not falling as would be expected.

Stevens suggested this all may be due to statistical flubs which will be corrected in due course (always a possibility), that maybe our population growth has not been as strong as previously thought and thus we’re not getting the usual benefit from such growth.

Or maybe, it is that what was once normal GDP growth of 3.2% is now above average.

Certainly the slow GDP per capita growth over the past 7 years would suggest things are not going along as usual:

5.22am BST

Falls in our exchange rate generally lead to rises in the cost of our imports. For now that really hasn’t been that big of a deal, because there was also a big fall in the price of oil (which alas, has now stopped falling and is back rising).

The rise in the price of goods and services which has a price determined on the world market (such as petrol and other imported goods) fell 0.3% in the past year:

The increase in the price of “non-tradable” goods and services – ie those which sees the price largely determined here in Australia, such as education, health costs, (some) food rose just 2.6%. This is well down on historical averages.

And certainly nothing there would have the RBA worried about inflation getting out of control. Indeed, given the weak inflation and weak wages growth figures, the RBA probably wouldn’t mind a bit more inflation. The Treasurer certainly would as stronger inflation and wage growth would see better tax revenue.

5.19am BST

Two reasons for the low dollar.

Firstly iron ore and coal prices plummeted. When a third of a country’s exports fall, the value of that country’s currency will usually fall with it

Secondly, the other big factor has been the improvement in the US economy and significantly the end of the US Federal Reserve’s policy of quantitative easing – where it bought a slew of US treasury bonds (around $3.5 trillion all up).

That policy devalued the worth of the US dollar. Now that it has finished, the value has improved. Since October last year the US dollar has increased in value by about 10% compared to its major trading partners.

Coupled with this is that after nearly seven years, both the Fed and Bank of England are looking like raising their official interest rates. The last time the Fed cut was in December 2008 – a time so long ago Malcolm Turnbull had only just got used to being called “opposition leader”, the most popular movie in Australia was the first Twilight film and Lady Gaga was the newest music sensation with Poker Face.

In the time since the Fed last changed interest rates, the RBA has changed them 19 times!

But the upshot is, if the Fed raises rates, it will have essentially the same (if not more) impact on the value of our currency as would the RBA cutting rates. So there will be little need for the RBA to worry about that when it makes up its mind in the next half hour.

5.13am BST

The dollar

One reason given in the past for the need for an interest rate cut has been to get the value of our dollar down.

Such a worry is well in the past now. Our dollar is worth around US$0.73 – roughly on or just a touch below the 30 year average, and 22% down on where it was in September last year:

5.08am BST

The slowing of the building approvals is happening pretty much across the country.

Of the states, only Tasmania appears to be showing signs of continued vigour.

5.07am BST

The impact of the new Apra speed limits has also seen banks move to try to dampen the investor market themselves.

All four of the big banks have in the past month raised the interest rates for investor housing loans by around 27 to 29 basis points.

This is exactly would you would expect to see occur with such “macroprudential tools”. Essentially what they hope will occur is that with a limit on investor lending, it takes some of the heat out of the property market, and allows the RBA to keep rates lower for longer.

Certainly the drop in non-housing approvals is a pretty obvious result. A couple of months ago it looked like for the first time non-housing approvals would be greater than housing approvals. Now that landmark looks to be put off for a bit longer:

5.01am BST

The fall in approvals of apartments – which are basically investor led construction (you don’t have many owner occupiers building an apartment block!) – comes off the back of some interesting findings regarding investor activity.

Figures which showed a jump in the numbers of properties being listed for sale in Sydney and Melbourne could be a sign that investors are rushing to get out of the market. Any changes in investor habits is largely being driven by moves by the Apra to limit such lending.

Last year it introduced “speed limits” wherein banks should not have credit growth for investor property loans going over 10%.

As Martin Farrer reported last week “the Commonwealth (10.2%), NAB (14%) and ANZ (12%) all topped the cap while Westpac, at 9.9%, just scraped below the limit”.

The most recent figures from the RBA show overall housing investor credit growing at 10.7% well in excess of that for owner-occupiers at 5.5%

4.53am BST

Last week also saw the release of the important building approvals data.

The RBA knows its most direct impact on the economy through cutting or raising interest rates comes via the building industry – specifically the residential market.

The latest figures showed a sharp drop in building approvals – falling 8.2% in seasonally adjusted terms, and 1.2% in trend terms. The drop was driven by a large fall in the number of approvals of non-house dwellings – ie flats and apartments.

As I noted a couple weeks ago, there is a large amount of such buildings which have been approved but on which building has yet to begin. This has led some to worry that there is a glut of apartment buildings coming down the construction tube.

The number of private sector non-house dwellings approved fell 20.8% in June. And while again those figures do bounce around a lot, the trend fall of 2.4% suggests it is not a flash in the pan occurrence:

Overall private sector building approvals rose 14.5% in the past year, but this also is down on previous months and suggests a peak has occurred.

4.46am BST

Retail sales up

Any hopes of a cut in rates were probably smashed with the release of the retail trade figures today.

They showed total turnover increased 0.7% in June in seasonally adjusted terms. That’s a pretty sizeable jump, but the seasonally adjusted figures do get a bit excitable. The trend growth of 0.3% is still nice and solid and produced a healthy annual increase of 4.7%:

This month also saw the quarterly release of volume of retail sales. It showed as well solid results, with total volume of sales up 3.3% in the past year, with the best results in the household goods retailing , which was up 10.5%:

That category includes electrical, computer and other assorted goods, and it certainly saw a bounce due to the release of the iphone 6 last year.

4.36am BST

The market expectations of interest rates haven’t changed a great deal in the past month. But if anything the market now remains more sure that another rate cut will occur – it’s just that they expect it will come later than it previously expected.

A month ago the market was expecting another rate cut anytime from the start of next year on. Now that expectation has been pushed out to April 2016.

Of course predictions this far out have a habit of being out by a large amount. It’s worth remembering that in April this year, the market was expecting rates by now to already have been cut to 1.75%. So being wrong four months out suggests we don’t place too much faith in expectations for what will occur next year.

4.22am BST

Good afternoon. Greg Jericho here.

Today most economists agree with the market pricing that suggests there is only a small chance of a rate cut. The market currently is pricing in just a 9% chance of a rate cut.

The decision comes after the release of the latest inflation and cost of living data late last month. The data showed that inflation remains very weak at just 1.5%, while the RBA’s “core inflation” measure of just 2.2% is well in the bottom half of its 2% to 3% range.

Thus while there seems little chance of a rate cut today, we will be looking for signs that the RBA is satisfied with the lower than usual level of growth or whether it still believes there is scope for the bank to give the economy another push later on in the year.

The additional capital that will be required to be held against residential mortgages will better align the banks’ capital positions with the growing tail risks arising from their residential mortgage exposures during a period of high investor demand and an associated rapid acceleration in house prices in Sydney and Melbourne.

And Moody’s notes that there could be more to come.

Seems unlikely but it’s going to a fascinating period for the Australian economy.
